item.content:encoded:
Category

Team Sport

Rules

The goal of the game is to throw the game balls so that they land as close as possible to the target ball known as the jack.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Sport for all

Playing sport has been a challenge for children with disabilities. Research shows how physical activities can uplift your mental health and motivate you to interact better.

BACKYARD PLAY

Easy activities and alternatives to sport equipment for playing at home.

SPORTS

Explore the various categories of sport available for people with disabilities.

MOTIVATIONAL STORIES

Inspirational stories of bravery and success in the face of adversity.

Sport Seeker Game

Go on an adventure and pick up sports equipment along the way to score points.Learn about sport positions, rules and equipment in this interactive game.

Beware of monsters along the way.

Backyard play

Check out these easy alternatives to sport activities to play at home.

Professional Sports

Explore the various categories of sport available for people with disabilities.


Sport Seeker

Game

Play Game

Go on an adventure and pick up sports equipment along the way to score points.

Sport for all

Playing sport has been a challenge for children with disabilities. Research shows how physical activities can uplift your mental health and motivate you to interact better.

BACKYARD PLAY

Easy activities and alternatives to sport equipment for playing at home.

SPORTS

Explore the various categories of sport available for people with disabilities.

MOTIVATIONAL STORIES

Inspirational stories of bravery and success in the face of adversity.

Sport Seeker Game

Go on an adventure and pick up sports equipment along the way to score points.Learn about sport positions, rules and equipment in this interactive game.

Beware of monsters along the way.

Backyard play

Check out these easy alternatives to sport activities to play at home.

Professional Sports

Explore the various categories of sport available for people with disabilities.


Sport Seeker

Game

Play Game

Go on an adventure and pick up sports equipment along the way to score points.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: http://sportseeker.ml.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: Backyard Play
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Backyard Bowling

Use a ball and recycled bottles to create your personal backyard bowling alley. Play with your wheelchair friends on a flat surface at home or in a park. https://youtu.be/FT-lfZL3uLs

Check out more activities below

Ball Toss

Play this fun game to get better at shooting the hoop and improve your basketball skills at home. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M1AQ24nv3X4 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hw1SQpfYsts

Backyard Volleyball

Practice your volleyball skills with this activity and increase your upper body strength.

Netball

Play this game to practice netball with your  friends for a fun afternoon outdoors. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_mSsYemz0shttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_uV2web45yg

Tabletop Shuffleboard

Use your table as a shuffleboard and slide bottle caps to see who can slide them the furthest to win.

Boccia

Play this tossing game with your friends to increase your aiming skills and coordination. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xlg9ptHjEa0

item.title: Boccia
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Prior to being introduced as a competitive sport at the New York 1984 Paralympic Games, Boccia was a popular recreation activity among school children and seniors. Boccia is a specialised disability sport in which players throw balls towards a target ball, known as a jack.

Facts

Rules

The goal of the game is to throw the game balls so that they land as close as possible to the target ball known as the jack.

Category

Team sport

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

item.title: Home 2 - Ash
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Anyone can play sport

Don't let your disability stop you from exploring and playing sport

Explore game

Sport Seeker Game

Check your mental and physical agility with this interactive game.

Backyard Play

Restricted by COVID? Explore these activities to stay active at home.

Professional Sport

Explore the categories of professional sport available for people with disabilities .

Benefits

game

The Sport Seeker game will explore different sport equipment to get a better understanding of sport using an interactive game and quiz. It aims at having fun while also informing you in the right methods to learn more about sports.

Find out more

Backyard Play

Learn how to play in a comfortableand healthyenvironment, with our comprehensive videos that explain how you can play with your friends or siblings at home or outdoor spaces. These activities are gears to make your body more flexible and agile.

Find out more

achieving your goals

Getting in shape forces you to face your biggest challenges, and sticking to a regular routine for a long period of time. Explore the various sports for speech/hearing impaired/wheelchair users along with contact details to ensure you know how to focus on team activities and sport to reach your goals.

Find out more

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: http:.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: Backyard play
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Backyard Play

Backyard Bowling

Use a ball and recycled bottles to create your personal backyard bowling alley. Play with your friends on a flat surface at home or in a park.

https://youtu.be/HtASgMyTJgE

Ball Toss

Play this fun game to get better at shooting the hoop and improve your basketball skills at home.

Backyard Volleyball

Practice your volleyball skills with this activity and increase your upper body strength.

https://youtu.be/w9uksYg2lWshttps://youtu.be/OQ0WskmxkT8

Boccia

Play this game to practice your aiming and throwing skills and challenge your friends.

Tabletop Shuffleboard

Use your table as a shuffleboard and slide bottle caps to see who can slide them the furthest to win.

https://youtu.be/d7gMMCK1Kwghttps://youtu.be/yRK7giNxsqo

Netball

Play this game to practice netball with your friends for a fun afternoon outdoors.

SPORT SEEKER GAME

Check your mental and physical agility with this interactive game.

PROFESSIONAL SPORT

Explore the categories of professional sport available for people with disabilities .

item.title: Wheelchair Basketball
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Wheelchair Basketball was one of the foundation sports on the Paralympic Program in Rome in 1960. Today, it is one of the most popular sports for athletes with a disability.

Facts

Rules

A player can push their wheelchair and bounce the ball simultaneously, however, if the ball is picked up and/or placed on the players lap, the player is only allowed to push twice before they are must shoot, pass, or dribble the ball again. There is no double dribble rule in wheelchair basketball.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Category

Team sport

item.title: Para Table Tennis
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Athletes from all physical and intellectual impairment groups can play table tennis, however, only eligible standing, sitting and intellectual impairment classes can compete at the Paralympic Games.

Facts

Rules

The object of the game is to use a racket/bat to hit the ball over the net onto the opponents side. A point is won if the other player fails to return it. Men and women can participate in individual and team events. A match consists of the best of 5 games. A game is won by the player or pair first scoring 11 points unless both players or pairs score 10 points. In this case the game is won by the first player or pair gaining a lead of 2 points.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users, Musculoskeletal disability, Neuro-musculo disability, Hearing and speech disability

Category

Team sport

item.title: Home5- Shivom
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
We are all Wonderfully made

FIND YOUR SPORT

I COULDN'T FIND A HERO IN MY LIFE SO I BECAME ONE.

Virtual Game

Go on an adventure and learn about sport positions, rules while picking sport equipment in this interactive game.Beware of monsters along the way.

Backyard Sports

Easy activities and alternatives to sport equipment for playing at home.

Professional Sports

Explore the various categories of sport available for people with disabilities.

Motivational Stories

Inspirational stories of bravery and success in the face of adversity.

item.title: SWIMMING
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Swimming

Swimming is Australias favourite pastime and is ingrained in the national identity. Living in a coastal country, the majority of Australians swim recreationally. Australians are strong competitive swimmers, with a large medal tally to show for it. The Australian Paralympic swim team ranked 2nd in the 2012 London games.Disciplines include Freestyle, Backstroke, Butterfly, Breaststroke and Medley events. Male and females of all abilities are able to participate and compete. Distances vary according to the athlete classification and the event.

Category

Individual Sport

Rules

Para-swimmers follow slightly modified rules of mainstream swimming. Athletes perform the standard strokes of their disciplines (Freestyle, Backstroke, Butterfly, Breastroke and Medley events, to the best of their ability. In able-bodied swimming, the race starts by competitors diving into the pool at the sound of a gun. If possible para-swimmers dive from the standing position. However, concessions are made and they can dive from a seated platform or start in the water. The regulation attire is a bathing suit. Like able-bodied swimming, athletes are forbidden to use any equipment that may enhance speed, buoyancy and endurance.

Suitable for

Musculo skeletal disability, Hearing and speech disability

Swimming Poster

Success story

Natalie du Toit

Para swimmer

Challenges

When Natalie was 17, she was hit by a car while riding her scooter back to school after leaving swim practice. The accident was bad, and she had to have her left leg amputated at the knee. This did not dampen her desire to compete in the Olympics. Three months after the accident, she was able to walk again and she started swimming again with a goal of competing in the 2002 Commonwealth games and the Olympics in the future.

Accomplishments
  • 200 m SM9 individual medley swimming gold medal Paralympics (2012)
  • 100 m S9 butterfly swimming gold medal Paralympics (2012)
  • 400 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal Paralympics (2012)
  • 100 m S9 freestyle swimming silver medal Paralympics (2012)
  • 100 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal Commonwealth Games (2010)
  • 100 m S9 butterfly swimming gold medal Commonwealth Games (2010)
  • 50 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal Commonwealth Games (2010)
  • 50 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal Paralympics (2008)
  • 400 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal Paralympics (2008)
  • 200 m SM9 individual medley swimming gold medal Paralympics (2008)
  • 100 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal Paralympics (2008)
  • 100 m S9 butterfly swimming gold medal Paralympics (2008)
  • 100 m freestyle swimming EAD (multi-disability) gold Commonwealth Games (2006)
  • 50 m freestyle swimming EAD (multi-disability) gold Commonwealth Games (2006)
  • 100 m S9 backstroke swimming silver medal Paralympics (2004)

The Australian Paralympic swim team ranked 2nd in the 2012 London games.Disciplines include Freestyle, Backstroke, Butterfly, Breaststroke and Medley events. Male and females of all abilities are able to participate and compete. Distances vary according to the athlete classification and the event.<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"1ca95acc","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"30","background_background":"classic","background_image":{"url":"http:\/\/www.sportseeker.tk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/3.jpg","id":73},"stretch_section":"section-stretched"},"elements":[{"id":"5ded654f","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":33,"_inline_size":19.364},"elements":[{"id":"5500d6d4","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"1807240","elType":"widget","settings":{"selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-certificate","library":"fa-solid"},"primary_color":"#000000"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon"},{"id":"786944ce","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Category","header_size":"h4","align":"center","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Delius Unicase","typography_font_weight":"600"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"16d39718","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Individual Sport<\/p>","align":"center","text_color":"#000000"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"71b8f51c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":33,"_inline_size":64.453},"elements":[{"id":"625e8322","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"28e7958b","elType":"widget","settings":{"selected_icon":{"value":"far fa-id-card","library":"fa-regular"},"primary_color":"#000000"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon"},{"id":"2744dba9","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Rules","header_size":"h4","align":"center","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Delius Unicase","typography_font_weight":"600"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"235b94d2","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Para-swimmers follow slightly modified rules of mainstream swimming. Athletes perform the standard strokes of their disciplines (Freestyle, Backstroke, Butterfly, Breastroke and Medley events, to the best of their ability. In able-bodied swimming, the race starts by competitors diving into the pool at the sound of a gun. If possible para-swimmers dive from the standing position. However, concessions are made and they can dive from a seated platform or start in the water. The regulation attire is a bathing suit. Like able-bodied swimming, athletes are forbidden to use any equipment that may enhance speed, buoyancy and endurance.<\/p>","align":"center","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Roboto","typography_font_weight":"400"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"19457909","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":33,"_inline_size":15.714},"elements":[{"id":"3310f6fc","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"6f37034d","elType":"widget","settings":{"selected_icon":{"value":"far fa-check-circle","library":"fa-regular"},"primary_color":"#000000"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon"},{"id":"204f955c","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Suitable for","header_size":"h4","align":"center","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Delius Unicase","typography_font_weight":"600"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"c7d912a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Para swimmer<\/p>","align":"center"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"6f8df116","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Challenges ","tab_content":"

When Natalie was 17, she was hit by a car while riding her scooter back to school after leaving swim practice. The accident was bad, and she had to have her left leg amputated at the knee. This did not dampen her desire to compete in the Olympics. Three months after the accident, she was able to walk again and she started swimming again with a goal of competing in the 2002 Commonwealth games and the Olympics in the future.<\/span><\/p>","_id":"4541d33"},{"_id":"30584bf","tab_title":"Accomplishments","tab_content":"

  • 200 m SM9 individual medley swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2012)<\/li>
  • 100 m S9 butterfly swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2012)<\/li>
  • 400 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2012)<\/li>
  • 100 m S9 freestyle swimming silver medal \u2013 Paralympics (2012)<\/li>
  • 100 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal \u2013 Commonwealth Games (2010)<\/li>
  • 100 m S9 butterfly swimming gold medal \u2013 Commonwealth Games (2010)<\/li>
  • 50 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal \u2013 Commonwealth Games (2010)<\/li>
  • 50 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2008)<\/li>
  • 400 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2008)<\/li>
  • 200 m SM9 individual medley swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2008)<\/li>
  • 100 m S9 freestyle swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2008)<\/li>
  • 100 m S9 butterfly swimming gold medal \u2013 Paralympics (2008)<\/li>
  • 100 m freestyle swimming EAD (multi-disability) gold \u2013 Commonwealth Games (2006)<\/li>
  • 50 m freestyle swimming EAD (multi-disability) gold \u2013 Commonwealth Games (2006)<\/li>
  • 100 m S9 backstroke swimming silver medal \u2013 Paralympics (2004)<\/li><\/ul>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: PARA ARCHERY
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Para Archery

Para-archery is a sport of precision, concentration and strength open to athletes with a physical disability.Thesporttestsaccuracy,strengthandconcentration.

Category

Individual or Team sport

Rules

Competitors shoot arrows at a target marked with ten scoring zones, from a set distance. Para-archery is very similar to able-bodied archery. Athletes shoot the same rounds, distances and events. The difference is para-athletes are divided into three functional classes - Standing, Wheelchair 1 and Wheelchair 2.

Suitable for

Musculoskeletal disability, Neuro-musculo disability, Wheelchair users, Hearing and speech disability

Para-Archery Poster

Success story

Matt Stutzman

Para archery athlete - Physical disability

Challenges

He was born in Kansas City without arms. He had to do everything one might normally do with one’s arms, with his feet. Matt comes from a family that hunts, and took up archery as a way to feed his family.

Accomplishments
  • Participated in the 2016 Paralympics
  • Won gold at the 2014 Parapan American Championships.
  • Won gold as a mixed team in the 2014 Parapan American Championships.
  • 2012 Paralympics silver medal.
  • Holds two national records in archery.
  • Holds the Guinness World Record for the longest accurate shot: 230 yards

item.title: PARA BADMINTON
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Para Badminton

Para-Badminton is a sport for all. Para-badminton is a sport which can be played by both men and women of any age with a physical impairment. It is a growing sport that is attracting more participants every year both competitively and socially.

Category

Team or Individual Sport

Rules

Like badminton, para-badminton is played on a rectangular court separated by a net with a shuttle. The aim of para-badminton is to, using a racquet, pass the shuttle from one side of the net to the opposing team on the other attempting to force an error in the opposition thus winning a point.
Simplified Scoring:A match consists of the best of 3 games of 21 points.A point is scored every time there is a serve.The side winning a rally adds a point to its score and serves the next rally. At 20 all, the side which gains a 2 point lead first, wins that game.At 29 all, the side scoring the 30th point, wins that game. The side winning a game serves first in the next game.Athletes compete in singles (men/women), doubles (men/women) and mixed doubles.

Suitable for

Hearing and speech impaired, Musculo-skeletal disability

Para-Badminton Poster

Success story

Manasi Girishchandra Joshi

Para badminton athlete - physical disability

Challenges

Manasi met with an accident on her way to work and had to amputate her leg. This moment of horror changed her life in a surprisingly positive way.

Accomplishments

After her horrific accident, she pursued para-badminton and treated it as part of her rehabilitation and became a member of the national team.

She won medals in different competitions:

  • 2015 medal in mixed doubles, Para-Badminton World Championships.
  • 2016 Bronze in women’s singles & women’s doubles, Para-Badminton Asian Championships.
  • 2017 Bronze in women’s singles, Para-Badminton World Championships.
  • 2018 Bronze in women’s singles, Thailand Para-Badminton International.
  • 2018 Bronze in women’s singles, Asian Para Games 2018.
  • 2019 Gold in women’s singles, Para-Badminton World Championship, Basel, Switzerland.

item.title: WHEELCHAIR BASKETBALL
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Wheelchair Basketball

Wheelchair Basketball was one of the foundation sports on the Paralympic Program in Rome in 1960. Today, it is the most popular sports for athletes with a disability.

Category

Team Sport

Rules

A player can push their wheelchair and bounce the ball simultaneously. If the ball is picked up or placed on the players lap, the player is only allowed to push their wheels twice before they must shoot, pass or dribble the ball again. There is no double dribble rule in wheelchair basketball.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Wheelchair Basketball Poster

Success story

Alana Nichols

Para basketball athlete 

Challenges

In 2000, Alana Nichols suffered a spinal cord injury while attempting a back-flip on her snowboard. Although paralyzed from the waist down, Alanas athletic career wouldnt be suppressed for long.

Accomplishments
  • Five-time Paralympian (2008, 2010, 2012, 2014, 2016); Six-time medalist (3 gold, 2 silver, 1 bronze)
  • 2016 Paralympic Games: KL2 (canoe)
  • 2014 Paralympic Winter Games: silver downhill, 4th giant slalom; U.S. Paralympics Alpine Skiing National Championships, 2nd slalom; Huntsman Cup, 1st giant slalom, 2nd slalom; World Cup Panorama, 2nd downhill, 2nd super-G, 3rd super combined; World Cup Copper Mountain, 5th giant slalom, 5th slalom; NorAm Aspen, 1st downhill; NorAm Winter Park, 1st giant slalom, 2nd slalom; U.S. Paralympics Alpine Skiing National Championships, 1st downhill and super-G
  • 2012 Paralympic Games: 4th (wheelchair basketball)
  • 2010 Paralympic Winter Games: gold downhill and giant slalom, silver super-G, bronze super combined
  • 2008 Paralympic Games: 1st (wheelchair basketball)

item.title: PARA TABLE TENNIS
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Para Table tennis

Athletes from all physical and intellectual impairment groups can play table tennis. Only eligible standing, sitting and intellectual impairment classes can compete at the Paralympic Games.

Category

Team Sport

Rules

The object of the game is to use a racket/bat to hit the ball over the net onto the opponents side. A point is won if the other player fails to return it. Men and women can participate in individual and team events. A match consists of the best of 5 games. A game is won by the player or pair first scoring 11 points unless both players or pairs score 10 points. In this case, the game is won by the first player or pair gaining a lead of 2 points.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users, Musculoskeletal disability, Neuro-musculo disability, Hearing and speech disability

Table Tennis Poster

Success story

Ibrahim Hamato

Para table tennis athlete

Challenges

Ibrahim suffered from a train accident when he was ten years old and he lost both arms. In an interview with CNN, he said that soccer and table tennis were the only two sports available for playing in his village. He chose table tennis as a challenge.

Accomplishments
  • 2013 African Championship.
  • 2011 African Championships.
  • 2013 Egypt Open.

item.title: PARA ATHLETICS
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Para Athletics

Athletics always attracts the highest number of spectators as the sport offers a wide range of competitions and events. It is open to male and female athletes in all impairment groups.

Category

Individual Sport

Rules

Athletics consists of multiple disciplines within the sport and as such has rules for each discipline.

Suitable for

Musculoskeletal disability, Neuro-musculo disability, Wheelchair users, Hearing and speech disability

Athletics Poster

Success story

Louise Sauvage

Wheelchair racing

Challenges

Sauvage was born with a severe congenital spinal condition called myelomeningocele. She had 21 surgeries before she turned ten. She suffered Scoliosis and also underwent a spinal surgery. She started competing in wheelchair sport at the age of eight and took up competitive wheelchair racing when she turned 15.

Accomplishments
  • Australian Paralympian of the Yearin 1994, 1996, 1997 and 1998
  • Australian Institute of Sport(AIS) Athlete of the year in 1997.
  • Female Athlete of the Year in theSport Australia Award in 2000.
  • Australian Sports Medalin 2000.
  • Sauvage carried the Australian flag into the stadium at the2004 Summer Paralympics.
  • Sauvage won the prestigiousOz Day 10K Wheelchair Road Raceten times from 1993 to 2003.

item.title: WHEELCHAIR HOCKEY
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Wheelchair Hockey

Electric wheelchair hockey is a modified version of ice hockey for electric wheelchair users. It is commonly known as Power hockey. The sport is played on an indoor basketball court rather than an ice rink. There are two teams of five players.

Category

Team Sport

Rules

Electric wheelchair hockey follows traditional ice hockey rules. However, it is modified to enable play by wheelchair athletes. It is played on a wooden surface instead of ice. A plastic ball is used instead of a hockey puck. Players use plastic T-shaped hockey sticks to hit the ball. The stick is held and operated by the player if their functionality permits this movement. Players with very limited range and movement can tape the stick to their wheelchair. Players are allocated one of five positions: Centre Goaltender Left Winger Right Winger Defencemen They can alternate positions during the game, provided there are five players on court at all times. The objective is to score a goal by hitting the ball across the oppositions goal line. The game is won by the team who scores the most goals.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Wheelchair Hockey poster

Success Story

Bill Siegloff

Para Ice Hockey player

Challenges

Bill smashed his knee caps and injured his back in an accident in the army. He started playing hockey with his son, Angus, and quickly became equipped as a defense player.

Accomplishments
  • Won 13 National and state titles in Rifle shooting.
  • Para national team player in the World championship.
  • Played in the nationals for both inline and para ice hockey.

item.title: POWER CHAIR FOOTBALL
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Powerchair Football

Powerchair football is a modified version of soccer for electric wheelchair users. It is played in a gymnasium on a regulation basketball court. There are two teams of four players, including the goal keeper. The objective is to score more goals than the opposing team.

Category

Team Sport

Rules

Powerchair football is played in specialized electric wheelchairs, called powerchairs. Each powerchair must have 4 or more wheels, a lap belt and a foot guard. The players use the foot guard to kick and block an over-sized soccer ball (33 cm in diameter). A goal is scored when the ball fully enters the oppositions goal area. The game is won by the team who scores the most goals. There are four players on each team, including the goalkeeper. The 40 minute game is split into 20 minute halves, with a 10 minute half time break. The game is similar to able-bodied soccer. However powerchair football has two distinguishing rules:Two-on-one:Only one player from each team is allowed within 3 metres of the ball on court (except in the goal area). This means teammates have to spread out which enables better game flow.3-in-the-goal-area:The defending team is only allowed 2 players in their own goal area. Able-bodied soccer has penalty throw-ins. However kick-ins are used in powerchair football because many players have impaired upper body function.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Powerchair Football poster

Success Story

Abdullah Karim

Powerchair Football player with scoliosis and limb deficiency.

Challenges

He was born with scoliosis and limb deficiency. His optimism and drive has helped him achieve heights in Powerchair football despite unimaginable obstacles.

Accomplishments
  • He is known as the Lionel Messi of Powerchair football.
  • Awarded as the Most Valuable Player at the 2017 Powerchair Football World Cup held in the United States.

item.title: BOCCIA
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Boccia

Bocciais a specialized disabilitysportin which the players throw balls towards a target ball, known as a jack.Prior to being introduced as a competitive sport at the New York 1984 Paralympic Games, Boccia was a popular recreation activity among school children and seniors.

Category

Team Sport

Rules

The goal of the game is to throw the game balls so that they land as close as possible to the target ball known as the jack.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Boccia Poster

Success story

David Smith

Para boccia athlete

Challenges

David was diagnosed with Cerebral Palsy when he was one. He had to go to the developmental center for disabled children. He never won a game and the sport took time to ignite his interest. Due to the lack of academic ability of his peers, his potential to learn was being held back.

Accomplishments

Rio 2016 Paralympic Games

  • Individual BC1: Gold

London 2012 Paralympic Games

  • Individual BC1: Silver
  • BC1/BC2 Team: Bronze

Beijing 2008 Paralympic Games

  • BC1/BC2 Team: Gold

2019 BISFed European Championships, Portugal

  • Individual BC1: Gold
  • BC1/BC2 Team: Bronze

2018 BISFed World Championships, Liverpool, UK

Individual BC1: Gold

2017 BISFed European Championships, Portugal

  • Individual BC1: Gold

2016 BISFed Boccia Individual World Championships, Beijing, China

  • Individual BC1: Bronze

2015 BISFed Boccia European Championships Team and Pairs, Surrey, UK

  • BC1/BC2 Team: Gold

2014 BESFed Boccia World Championships, Beijing, China

  • Individual BC1: Gold

2013 BISFed European Championships Guimaraes, Portugal

  • Individual BC1: Gold
  • BC1/BC2 Team: Bronze

item.title: Para Athletics
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Athletics always attracts the highest number of spectators as the sport offers a wide range of competitions and events and is open to male and female athletes in all impairment groups.

Facts

Rules

Athletics consists of multiple disciplines within the sport and as such has rules for each discipline.

Category

Individual

Suitable for

Musculoskeletal disability, Neuro-musculo disability, Wheelchair users, Hearing and speech disability

item.title: Wheelchair Hockey
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Electric wheelchair hockey is a modified version of ice hockey for electric wheelchair users. It is commonly known as Power hockey. The sport is played on an indoor basketball court rather than an ice rink. There are two teams of five players.

Facts

Rules

Electric wheelchair hockey follows traditional ice hockey rules. However, it is modified to enable play by wheelchair athletes. It is played on a wooden surface instead of ice. A plastic ball is used instead of a hockey puck. Players use plastic T-shaped hockey sticks to hit the ball. The stick is held and operated by the player if their functionality permits this movement. Players with very limited range and movement can tape the stick to their wheelchair. Players are allocated one of five positions: Centre Goaltender Left Winger Right Winger Defencemen They can alternate positions during the game, provided there are five players on court at all times. The objective is to score a goal by hitting the ball across the oppositions goal line. The game is won by the team who scores the most goals.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Category

Team sport

item.title: Powerchair Football
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Powerchair football is a modified version of soccer for electric wheelchair users. It is played in a gymnasium on a regulation basketball court. There are two teams of four players (including the goal keeper). The objective is to score more goals than the opposing team.

Facts

Rules

Powerchair football is played in specialised electric wheelchairs, called powerchairs. Each powerchair must have 4 or more wheels, a lap belt and a foot guard. The players use the foot guard to kick and block an over-sized soccer ball (33 cm in diameter). A goal is scored when the ball fully enters the oppositions goal area. The game is won by the team who scores the most goals. There are four players on each team, including the goalkeeper. The 40 minute game is split into 20 minute halves, with a 10 minute half time break. The game is similar to able-bodied soccer. However powerchair football has two distinguishing rules: Two-on-one: Only one player from each team is allowed within 3 metres of the ball on court (except in the goal area). This means teammates have to spread out which enables better game flow. 3-in-the-goal-area: The defending team is only allowed 2 players in their own goal area. The penalty for infracting either of these rules is loss of possession and or/ a free kick-in from the sideline for the opposition. Able-bodied soccer has penalty throw-ins. However kick-ins are used in powerchair football because many players have impaired upper body function.

Suitable for

Wheelchair users

Category

Team sport

item.title: Swimming
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Swimming is Australias favourite pastime and is ingrained in the national identity. Living in a coastal country, the majority of Australians swim recreationally. Australians are strong competitive swimmers, with a large medal tally to show for it. The Australian Paralympic swim team ranked 2nd in the 2012 London games.Disciplines include Freestyle, Backstroke, Butterfly, Breaststroke and Medley events. Male and females of all abilities are able to participate and compete. Distances vary according to the athlete classification and the event.

Facts

Rules

Para-swimmers follow slightly modified rules of mainstream swimming. Athletes perform the standard stroke/s of their disciplines (Freestyle, Backstroke, Butterfly, Breastroke and Medley events, to the best of their ability. In able-bodied swimming, the race starts by competitors diving into the pool at the sound of a gun. If possible para-swimmers dive from the standing position. However, concessions are made and they can dive from a seated platform or start in the water. The regulation attire is a bathing suit. Like able-bodied swimming, athletes are forbidden to use any equipment that may enhance speed, buoyancy and endurance.

Suitable for

Musculo skeletal disability, Hearing and speech disability

Category

Individual sport

item.title: Para Archery
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Para-archery is a sport of precision, concentration and strength open to athletes with a physical disability.Thesporttestsaccuracy,strengthandconcentration.

Facts

Rules

Competitors shoot arrows at a target marked with ten scoring zones, from a set distance. Para-archery is very similar to able-bodied archery. Athletes shoot the same rounds, distances and events. The difference is para-athletes are divided into three functional classes - Standing, Wheelchair 1 and Wheelchair 2.

Suitable for

Musculoskeletal disability, Neuro-musculo disability, Wheelchair users, Hearing and speech disability

Category

Individual or Team sport

item.title: Para Badminton
item.dc:creator: Ash
item.content:encoded:
Para Badminton

Para-Badminton is a sport for all. Para-badminton is a sport which can be played by both men and women of any age with a physical impairment. It is a growing sport that is attracting more and more participants every year both competitively and socially.

Category

Team Sport

Rules

Like badminton, para-badminton is played on a rectangular court separated by a net with a shuttle. The aim of para-badminton is to, using a racquet, pass the shuttle from one side of the net to the opposing team on the other attempting to force an error in the opposition thus winning a point.
Simplified Scoring: A match consists of the best of 3 games of 21 points.A point is scored every time there is a serve.The side winning a rally adds a point to its score and serves the next rally. At 20 all, the side which gains a 2 point lead first, wins that game.At 29 all, the side scoring the 30th point, wins that game. The side winning a game serves first in the next game.Athletes compete in singles (men/women), doubles (men/women) and mixed doubles.

Suitable for

Hearing and speech impaired, Musculo skeletal disability.

Facts

Rules

Like badminton, para-badminton is played on a rectangular court separated by a net with a shuttle. The aim of para-badminton is to, using a racquet, pass the shuttle from one side of the net to the opposing team on the other attempting to force an error in the opposition thus winning a point.
Simplified Scoring: A match consists of the best of 3 games of 21 points.A point is scored every time there is a serve.The side winning a rally adds a point to its score and serves the next rally. At 20 all, the side which gains a 2 point lead first, wins that game.At 29 all, the side scoring the 30th point, wins that game. The side winning a game serves first in the next game.Athletes compete in singles (men/women), doubles (men/women) and mixed doubles.

Suitable for

Hearing and speech impaired, Musculo-skeletal disability

Category

Team sport

item.title: Tabletop Shuffleboard
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Tabletop Shuffleboard

Use your table as a shuffleboard and slide bottle caps to see who can slide them the furthest to win.

Watch the video to learn more.

https://youtu.be/d7gMMCK1Kwg

Explore more activities

Previous Next

Backyard Boccia

Play this game to practice your aiming and throwing skills and challenge your friends.

Watch the video to learn more. https://youtu.be/OQ0WskmxkT8

Explore more activities
